title: Add Standard Groupings
text: light sample sizes, breakdowns PSRC’s Household Travel Survey instrument often involve category groupings less granular reported level detail. psrc.travelsurvey functions provide commonly utilized groupings, can considered agency standard variables interest. Although new variable specific one unit analysis (.e. hh, person, day, trip, vehicle), first argument grouping function entire hts_data object, order facilitate piping. one standard grouping exists variable, function returns , convenience; can distinguished suffix denoting number categories. functions require disaggregate input variable requested earlier get_psrc_hts() call. input variable output variable included resulting hts_data object. Currently, following functions exist, along required input variable.
code: library(psrc.travelsurvey) library(magrittr) library(data.table)  # Specify which variables to retrieve vars <- c("age", "hhsize")  # Retrieve the data hts_data <- get_psrc_hts(survey_year=2023, survey_vars = vars)   # Add standard groupings for age and household size # -- Notice age and hhsize use different tables (person, hh) # -- but you don't need to worry about that; the package knows hts_data <- hts_data %>%    hts_bin_age() %>%   hts_bin_hhsize()  hts_data$person[, head(.SD), .SDcols=patterns("^age")] #>            age       age_bin5       age_bin3 #>          <ord>         <fctr>         <fctr> #> 1: 45-54 years    45-64 Years    18-64 Years #> 2: 16-17 years Under 18 Years Under 18 Years #> 3: 12-15 years Under 18 Years Under 18 Years #> 4: 35-44 years    25-44 Years    18-64 Years #> 5: 25-34 years    25-44 Years    18-64 Years #> 6: 25-34 years    25-44 Years    18-64 Years

title: Retrieve and summarize data
text: psrc.travelsurvey package meant complement enhance travelSurveyTools package PSRC users. delivers data hts_data format appropriate input subsequent travelSurveyTools functions. also provides wrapper functions provide PSRC defaults travelSurveyTools functions, resulting simpler workflows fewer required arguments. psrc.travelsurvey constrained extent fitting travelSurveyTools system, suggestions features functions ’d find helpful, please contact authors ’ll see can implement .

title: Retrieve and summarize data
text: Since psrc.travelsurvey uses Elmer, agency’s central database, retrieve PSRC household travel survey data ’ll need connected (office via VPN). use get_psrc_hts(), takes two arguments: survey_years - vector one years; default available .e., c(2017,2019,2021,2023) writing. survey_vars - vector variable names (regardless table occur) return object list separate data.table elements potential unit analysis, .e. household (hh), person, day, trip, vehicle. travelSurveyTools package workflow uses central object related independent variable summaries. can include full set variables summaries, ’s unnecessary request separate data objects feed separate summary data table. also supports multiyear summaries (trends/comparisons) via survey_year field. efficiency, get_psrc_hts() requests variables specify, must know precise names. lookup function, psrc_hts_varsearch() can assist; takes single string argument codebook search term matches either variable name description fields. Regular expressions supported complex searches; example, word boundary operator \\b can used omit vehicle model results searching “mode”. browse entire variable list, open internal data object init_variable_list: Note: unnecessary include survey year, table ids, weights, survey stratification variable (sample_segment) survey_vars argument; since necessary later steps, get_psrc_hts() includes implicitly. Factor variables levels applied codebook, missing skip-value codes recoded NA.

title: Retrieve and summarize data
text: summarize data, use psrc_hts_stat(). four primary arguments, one option. arguments : hts_data - hts_data object analysis_unit - string specifying scale statistics calculated, either “hh”, “person”, “day”,“trip”, “vehicle”. group_vars - grouping variables, nesting order (share summaries calculated per categories variable listed last). stat_var (optional) - Numeric variable min/max/median/mean desired; omit count/share summaries. example, ’ll retrieve following survey variables, one count/share summary, one numeric summary. Notice, travelSurveyTools handles relational element data, tables lower organizational heirarchy (like trips) inherit attributes (hh); handy feature avoids unnecessary data duplication among tables.
code: library(psrc.travelsurvey) library(data.table)  # Specify which variables to retrieve vars <- c("hhsize", "employment", "commute_mode", "dest_purpose",           "mode_characterization", "distance_miles")  # Retrieve the data hts_data <- get_psrc_hts(survey_vars = vars)  # default includes all survey_years    # Calculate a numeric summary, i.e. min/max/median/mean rs1 <- psrc_hts_stat(hts_data,                       analysis_unit="trip",                       group_vars="hhsize",                       stat_var="distance_miles")  head(dplyr::select(rs1[survey_year==2023], -c(survey_year, min, max))) #>      hhsize count      mean   mean_moe   median #>       <ord> <int>     <num>      <num>    <num> #> 1: 1 person 10075  6.380222  0.8284701 2.169828 #> 2: 2 people 11871 13.174915  3.0272559 3.311287 #> 3: 3 people  3517  8.357221  0.9016603 4.094215 #> 4: 4 people  3595 10.254066  5.6922574 3.233616 #> 5: 5 people  1018 32.329314 19.3722674 2.761995 #> 6: 6 people   371  5.709866  0.8525478 3.046583  # Calculate a categorical summary, i.e. count/share rs2 <- psrc_hts_stat(hts_data, "trip", c("hhsize", "mode_characterization"))  head(dplyr::select(rs2[survey_year==2023 & as.character(mode_characterization)=="Transit"],                    -c(survey_year, mode_characterization))) #>      hhsize count       prop    prop_moe       est   est_moe #>       <ord> <int>      <num>       <num>     <num>     <num> #> 1: 1 person   908 0.08090005 0.012606740 173635.72 28466.102 #> 2: 2 people   563 0.02056404 0.004167832  88135.46 17783.128 #> 3: 3 people   165 0.01946050 0.005394446  32299.75  8864.421 #> 4: 4 people   205 0.04214847 0.009085101 162495.97 35391.190 #> 5: 5 people    77 0.06091950 0.015838454 131608.22 34802.763 #> 6: 6 people    49 0.10200039 0.026777949 140783.94 38384.352

title: Retrieve and summarize data
text: Since hts_data element data.table, can manipulated combination base r, tidyverse (e.g. mutate()), data.table (e.g :=) syntax. example illustrates adding variables specific hts_data$trip element. Notice, inheritance capability mentioned earlier applies custom variables well, want recode household-level variable feature trip-level analysis, just add hts_data$hh (hts_data$trip). Standard category groupings present base data can added via functions described accompanying vignette. take entire hts_data object argument, specific table (package knows involved). lends piping multiple standard recodes. Keep mind filtering table removes records available subsequent analyses. Rather manage multiple filtered copies data object, may want create new variable relevant table NA values records intend exclude summary. can use incl_na=FALSE option exclude line summary results (particular value want shares calculated reported categories). calculate mode split percentages work trips adding variable coded NA non-work-related trips, using incl_na=FALSE option limit statistics category. Note: travelSurveyTools summary functions require additional preparatory steps psrc.travelsurvey handles , simplicity. use native travelSurveyTools summary functions, ’ll need handle extra steps , since travelSurveyTools dependency psrc.travelsurvey package.
code: library(dplyr) library(stringr)  # Use a standard variable recode to get simpler trip purpose hts_data <- hts_bin_dest_purpose(hts_data)  # Use dplyr::mutate to add a simplified mode field & work purpose specifier hts_data$trip <- mutate(   hts_data$trip,    purpose_work = case_when(     dest_purpose_bin4=="Work" ~ "Work",     !is.na(dest_purpose_bin4) ~ NA_character_),   mode_basic = case_when(     mode_characterization=="Airplane"                 ~NA_character_,     str_detect(mode_characterization, "HOV")          ~"HOV2+",     mode_characterization=="Drive SOV"                ~"Drive alone",     str_detect(mode_characterization, "^(Walk|Bike)") ~"Walk/Bike/Micromobility",     TRUE ~mode_characterization) )   # Calculate a categorical summary, i.e. count/share rs3 <- psrc_hts_stat(hts_data, "trip", c("purpose_work", "mode_basic"), incl_na=FALSE)  head(dplyr::select(rs3[survey_year==2023],                    -c(survey_year, purpose_work))) #>                 mode_basic count       prop    prop_moe        est   est_moe #>                     <char> <int>      <num>       <num>      <num>     <num> #> 1:             Drive alone  2734 0.79225316 0.022564259 1811897.29 115484.22 #> 2:                   HOV2+   338 0.09876046 0.019141481  225866.97  45747.05 #> 3:                 Transit   419 0.03180004 0.007017877   72727.26  15812.50 #> 4: Walk/Bike/Micromobility   846 0.07718633 0.011570575  176526.54  26040.61
